data.author: mrhanji
data.content: AI Overview Based on recent interviews with Proactive Investors, Quantum Blockchain Technologies PLC (AIM:QBT) is in a high-intensity phase of commercializing its AI-driven Bitcoin mining technology, with a particular focus on its "Method C" AI Oracle. Here are the key takeaways from recent QBT interviews with CEO Francesco Gardin: 1. Key Technology Developments Method C AI Oracle: This is the main focus, designed to improve the efficiency of existing ASIC mining hardware. It has been refined to operate in real-time using FPGA hardware, with the aim of achieving roughly a 30% increase in "quality hashes" (efficiency). Software-Only Deployment: To accelerate time-to-market, QBT shifted from a hardware-intensive approach to a software-only version of Method C, cutting deployment time from 18 months to just a few weeks. Methods A & B: These methods are also being developed, with ongoing negotiations to integrate them into aftermarket control boards for mining rigs. 2. Commercialization & Strategic Partnerships ASIC Partnerships: QBT has signed multiple Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs) with major, but unnamed, ASIC manufacturers to test the Method C AI Oracle on their machines. Testing Phase: The company is currently testing its technology in a Milan laboratory, focusing on legacy S9 miners as a proof of concept. Target Market: The technology is aimed at helping smaller or mid-sized miners, as well as those using older hardware, to close the efficiency gap with market leaders. Revenue Model: QBT is exploring several revenue avenues, including licensing fees, share of hash rates (profit sharing), and direct mining. 3. Recent Strategic Updates (Late 2025/Early 2026) Positive Feedback: The technology was well-received at a recent US Bitcoin conference, validating the company's direction. IP Strategy: QBT is focusing on patenting its core AI Oracle technology, though some developments are kept as trade secrets. The company describes this period as a "very, very intense and busy" time as they move towards full commercialization of their proprietary AI, which aims to boost hashing power without requiring significant extra energy.

data.author: UserSteve
data.content: [Part 2 of 2] ... we can start to develop our method on this open source platform, and that the expectation is that now that these three ASIC manufacturer [sic] will be selling their chips, unlike what the Chinese have been, manufacturer have been doing so far that they don't sell their chip, you have to de-solder their chip from a machine to use them. So this is creating a new, entirely new situation in the sector. Finally you have chips available in quantities, and you have already have the entire design of a system, of, of, a, a, an ecosystem for mining, and this is for us is a game-changer because we expect, or the industry expect, that there will be many manufacturers who will assemble systems, starting from this open source designs, and therefore there will be more companies offering their systems, which will bring a very healthy change in this market dominated by 99% by the three manufacturers in China. Host: Francesco, there's been confusion around partial access to source code. Can you explain in simple terms what access QBT has today, and what it doesn't yet have? Gardin: Yeah, that's has to do with the three, ahh, umm, with three partners, the ASIC manufacturers, because there is substantial amount of source code and they start to release it to us, err, umm, partially, er, because, er, erm, we wouldn't have anyway the, the ability to deal with three, err, different operating system [sic], ahh, three different drivers, and so that's something that is going on incrementally, err, but, ahh, it's, it's part of, of an agreed, ahh, erm, path, er, that, er, we have, er, defined with this, er, three potential partners. Host: Mmm. I mean, ahh, investors are keen to understand progress with those partners. How would you describe the current stage of those relationships and why the phase is taking time? Gardin: Ahhh, well, I mean *laughs* the, say that, ahh, the main focus with the three manufacturers, but not the only but main work focus is Method C. Method C you need to train the neural network [sic] and train it on the specific ASICs that will be in the machine. So the training is very ASIC oriented, specific ASIC oriented, and that's not something you do overnight, and to get these machines there is legal paperwork because one thing is to sign an NDA, the other thing is to sign all the guarantees for the software, the proprietary software that they share, the design of this ASIC because we need to understand how they work internally, the specs of these ASICs which are not necessarily in the public domain, so, I mean, it's not as simple as I sign an NDA, I come and pick up a machine tomorrow. *laughs and shakes head* Unfortunately it doesn't work like that. Host: Francesco, hope you'll continue to keep us updated with your progress, thank you very much for your time today. Gardin: Thank you Host: Francesco Gardin, the CEO of Quantum Blockchain Technologies.

data.content: Francesco Gardin interview 4 Feb 2026 This thread contains a transcript of the Proactive Investors interview with Francesco Gardin on 4 Feb 2026 (Link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=73Vn7tzv1iI) The full interview starts at time 0:20. The first few words spoken from time 00:00 to 00:18 are a repeat of what was stated in the full interview at time 05:06 to 05:24. My transcript covers the full complete interview from 0:20 onwards; it does not contain the repeated words. This transcript was generated solely by me by hand (and ears) without using any tools or sources other than a word processor and listening to the YouTube video. I have not used any transcript generated by YouTube or any other software, tool, or source. ------------------- [Part 1 of 2] Host: Hello, you're watching Proactive. I'm joined by Francesco Gardin, the CEO of Quantum Blockchain Technologies. Francesco, very good to speak with you. Your update todays follows a positive industry conference rather than a single breakthrough. What was the key takeaway for QBT from attending the Nashville event? Gardin: Ok, good morning, Stephen. Ahh, the Bitcoin Park in Nashville is one of the center [sic] ah, in the US of the bitcoin culture. And so, ah, attending this events is always very important because it's the best way to network with the real professionals in the sector. Err, so it's been, ahh, one-and-a-half days but extremely intensive with the many, many, many, many side meetings that we had with the main players, especially with three, ahh, manufacturers of ASIC [sic] for bitcoin mining that we, ah, have signed the NDA with, and we are progressing, ahh, work with them, which is extremely good, and it's also good to show your face there and to show your physical presence together with our US consultants. Ahh, the, errm, so this is part of the normal commercial relationship, err, business relationship that you have to entertain and also monitor any development in the industry. Apart from this, it was very important for us also because one of the major problem that we had to face in the past is that 99% of the market is dominated by the Chinese manufacturers, and their policy is that no specs on the ASICs, err, and no availability of access to the software which runs on their mining rigs. Therefore that fact that now, finally, other after this gigantic effort, ahh, there is this whole stack available which is open source from the design of the hashing boards, design of control boards, the software which controls it, the even a pool, now is all open source which means that we can, ah, ah, as well as working with the three partners, the ASIC manufacturers, ... [continued in part 2]

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: For balance, the recent RNS can also be viewed constructively: • QBT confirmed continued engagement with ASIC manufacturers who have signed NDAs, suggesting partnerships remain in place and active. • The RNS states partial access to source code has already been granted, which may indicate progress into deeper technical collaboration rather than early-stage discussions. • Discussions around hardware and software delivery timelines suggest projects are moving toward integration and testing phases. • The RNS highlights QBT’s ability to work alongside emerging open-source mining hardware platforms, which could expand potential commercial routes and reduce supplier dependency. • Continued attendance at industry conferences supports relationship building, technical monitoring, and commercial visibility within the mining sector. The RNS does not announce immediate revenue or contract milestones but may indicate that development and partnership processes remain ongoing rather than stalled. Again, Investors should consider both positive signals and associated risks when interpreting company updates, and be mindful the consistent naysaying   rhetoric from the majority of the posters.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: For balance, If you remove the share bashers that popped out of the woodwork today  (as they always do on RNS days)  the interview can also be viewed positively in several ways: • QBT confirmed ongoing engagement with three ASIC manufacturers under NDAs, suggesting partnerships remain active. • Partial source code access indicates collaboration has progressed beyond early discussions into technical integration stages. • ASIC-specific training and legal/licensing steps help explain development timelines and reflect normal hardware/AI co-development complexity. • The emergence of open-source mining hardware could reduce reliance on dominant Chinese suppliers and create wider commercial opportunities. • Parallel development (partners + open stack) potentially reduces single-partner risk and increases long-term optionality. The interview does indicate continued technical and partnership progress rather than project inactivity. As always, investors should weigh both opportunities and risks and rely on primary disclosures when forming conclusions. Especially when the hoards are claiming white is black.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: How Narratives Sometimes Form Worth remembering that forum sentiment doesn’t always build randomly. There’s a common pattern that appears across many AIM and small-cap boards and in particular this. RNS brings out droves. It usually starts with a strong negative or positive claim. Then follow-up posts repeat or reinforce it. Over time, repetition can make opinions feel like established facts, even when no new evidence has been added. You have seen this before right ? Another common tactic is presenting complex technical points in a way that suggests confusion or contradiction. Readers can mistake complexity for proof something is wrong. Examples of Common Posting Styles Seen Across Discussions: • Pedrobull – Often posts short, slogan-style negativity or repetition phrases that reinforce sentiment rather than introduce new information. • Phimx – Frequently posts longer technical or RNS-based interpretations, often highlighting perceived contradictions or uncertainty in company communications. • riceyboy84 – Commonly posts timeline predictions and worst-case scenario outcomes such as delisting or failure, usually framed as inevitability. • KoolKat15 – Often focuses on investor protection arguments, confidence issues, and the absence of revenue or deals, typically presented in detailed opinion posts. • allforprofit – Tends to use strong criticism of leadership capability or company direction, often framed as performance concern commentary. • 0134 – Regularly raises concerns around funding, placings, or financial sustainability speculation. • Plutuq – Often posts probability or price prediction style commentary suggesting likely short-term trading outcomes. • Awl007 – Typically posts shorter reinforcement or agreement style comments that echo broader sentiment already expressed. • mrhanji – Usually posts bullish outlook commentary, often focusing on potential partnerships, future valuation upside, or encouraging holders to ignore negative sentiment. These observations relate to posting style patterns only and form part of normal forum debate dynamics seen across many shares and boards. But WHY so many self proclaimed uninvested users spreading negativity ? None of this means criticism or support is invalid. Healthy debate is important. It simply means investors should separate: • Evidence • Interpretation • Repetition • Emotion Always worth checking source material yourself rather than relying purely on forum consensus.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: Common pattern seen on this thread: 🔹 Technical scepticism usually starts with posters like Phimx and UserSteve They quote RNS wording, highlight contradictions, and build logical arguments suggesting delays or lack of clarity. 🔹 Strategic doubt often follows from posters like Hexam They expand the discussion into partner engagement, company direction, or credibility of progress. 🔹 Emotional escalation then appears via posters like riceyboy84 and avocet123 This is where language shifts towards “jam tomorrow”, funding fears, or leadership criticism. 🔹 Confidence erosion framing is often reinforced by KoolKat15 Posts focus on lack of revenue, investor risk, and long-term trust concerns. 🔹 Echo reinforcement typically comes from shorter posts by Badboxer, MDL26, Drutor, and Plutuq These reinforce sentiment through humour, certainty statements, or price predictions. 🔹 Bullish counter arguments usually come from mrhanji Posts highlight potential deals, progress indicators, and future rerate scenarios. 🔹 Neutral sentiment or market reaction comments often appear from Awl007 and oldsharedog None of this means anyone is right or wrong. It simply shows how forum sentiment can build through layered interaction rather than single opinions. Again have you seen these names interacting before? Always worth separating: • Evidence • Interpretation • Repetition • Emotion

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: There’s a big gap between the hype generated on bulletin boards and what’s actually happening with QBT. The hype is built on: extrapolating worst-case interpretations, recycling old quotes out of context, asserting certainty where there is none, and treating opinion or inference as if it were established fact. What’s actually happening is simpler: QBT has been running an R&D programme with multiple approaches, descriptions have evolved as implementations are tested, progress has been slower than hoped (as is common in R&D), and outcomes ultimately depend on independent verification, not forum rhetoric. None of that proves success, but neither does repetition of negative narratives prove failure. The only things that will settle this are evidence, testing results, and disclosures. Until then, most of what’s posted here is noise layered on top of opinion. Readers should separate certainty-sounding posts from verifiable facts, and decide accordingly.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: At this point there isn’t any additional evidence or material information being introduced,  we’re  just restating positions. The disclosures say what they say, interviews say what they say, and the outcome is known. Readers can draw their own conclusions from the primary sources. There’s nothing further of substance to add here.

data.author: UserSteve
data.content: Mikeydj said "The RNS said 'NDA signed' and “'ocus on development',  it did not commit to manufacture, spend, or production. " I agree with you, Mikeydj. The RNS most definitely did not say that they *will* produce an ASIC. But in the 3 Dec 2021 public interview, their CEO Gardin *did* say that QBT's target was to produce an ASIC that was, at a minumum, twice as fast as the keading ASIC at the time, within one year. His guidance is not caveated; these are stated as definites. Gardin states "The chip that *we will produce*...". This is definite guidance with no caveats, if, buts, mights, or maybes. Gardin also states the chip "...will be more faster than just twice as much. Twice as much faster is the minimum target for our chip...". Again, this is definite performance guidance with no caveats. Gardin also states "I emphasise that [these results] are a 1 year away target.". Here the CEO is giving guidance that their target is to produce the ASIC in a year. No caveats at all. There are two ways to look at this. The first is to accept that QBT completely failed to achieve their guidance target stated publically by their CEO. The second is to accept that anything their CEOs say in public interviews is unreliable, may not reflect reality, and should not be used to influence your investment decisions.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: To be clear, no one suggested a 5nm ASIC costs “£32”. The point is that 5nm costs vary enormously depending on scope, IP reuse, verification depth, and whether work is development, prototyping, or mass production. Presenting a single headline figure as universally applicable , even if described as “design only” , still ignores those variables. Sarcasm doesn’t change that technical reality.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: The RNS said “NDA signed” and “focus on development”, it did not commit to manufacture, spend, or production. Quoting a single $449m 5nm cost figure applies to full-scale SoC programmes, not automatically to every ASIC concept or development path. Interviews are not guidance and don’t override what is (and isn’t) stated in RNS disclosures. Collapsing those distinctions into “we know it was impossible” isn’t analysis, it’s framing. Readers can judge intent by comparing what was actually committed to in writing versus how it’s being retrospectively portrayed.

data.author: UserSteve
data.content: While the RNS very clearly does not state that QBT intends to actually make the 5nm ASIC, investors could be forgiven for believing that this was their intention. Investors would have got this impresdion from the public statements of CEO Gardin during the 3 Dec 2021 Proactive Investor interview (link at bottom). Here are some of Gardin's statements regarding the ASIC: At 03:05 Gardin says "It was quite complex to be able to attract the attention of this large [5nm ASIC] manufacturer and actually being able to engage them and to book some production time at the beginning of Q1 2023" At 04:14 Gardin says "The chip that we will produce will be far more faster than just twice as much. Twice as much faster is the minimum target for our chip, but we are confident that it will be much, much faster when we introduce the results of the second patent" and "I emphasise that [these results] are a 1 year away target." Then at 05:14 Gardin says "We are getting extraordinary results from our AI team which means if we can incorporate those results into our chip, our chip could be 100 times, 1000 times faster." But as Mikeydj rightly posted, interviews are not guidance and can be disregarded. I would go further and will state the obvious: that after this debacle, all of Gardin's claims during interviews can be safely ignored as hopelessly fantastical delusions of grandeur which have never have and never will be borne out in the real world. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uyx67cydEMI

data.author: UserSteve
data.content: Ah yes, but you need to identify the multiple caveats used in the RNS, "focus" and "develoment": "...it has made the key decision to *focus on* the *development of* the more efficient 5nm ... ASIC..." They only said they were going to *focus on it*, they never said they were going to actually make one. And they only said they were going to focus on the *development* of one, they never said they were going to actually make one. So it was there in black and white that they only intended to have a look into it, they never said they intended to make one. All QBT's RNSs must be very carefully read to identify the caveats used. When you do, you will find that they claim or intend to do very little indeed.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: here are specific phrases, labels, and rhetorical constructions used by phimx on many occasions that read to a reasonable reader as implying fraud, deception, or scam-like behaviour. even when he later retreats behind “opinion” or “technical critique”. 1. explicit deception / dishonesty framing these are not neutral technical criticisms , they imply intentional misleading: “gardin has continually changed the story” “covered up the flaws in his story” “layers of bull**** on top of more bull****” “making up the numbers to fit the claims” “chosen to sound plausible to non-engineers” “hand-waving” (repeated in context of official disclosures) these phrases frame management behaviour as knowingly deceptive rather than mistaken or speculative. 2. competence / dishonesty escalation this is a classic technique: start with “ignorance”, end at fraud: “gardin didn’t understand the hashing process” “neither did i” (false humility used to appear balanced) “where was the expertise?” “no team of experts could have existed” “fantasy” / “abandoned fantasy” “mistaken asic route” “failed asic route”

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: So, to be clear, are you saying that YES you did  very much do in fact use the term “covered up” in this thread below ?, i did not see a reply. What you are describing is your reconstruction of how Method C must have evolved, based on your current understanding of mining architecture. That is not the same thing as demonstrating a contradiction in disclosed statements. Two points matter here: Change of implementation detail is not a contradiction of claim The core claim has remained that an AI-driven oracle can influence which work is prioritised or discarded before full hashing. Whether that logic sits on an ASIC, FPGA, control board, or software layer  is an implementation choice, not a reversal of principle. R&D projects routinely move functionality across layers as constraints are better understood. You are explicitly speculating about motives and competence Phrases like “I speculate that Gardin finally realised…” and “ignorance rather than development” are interpretations, not facts. You may believe them to be likely, but they are not supported by any evidence stating “this approach was abandoned because we misunderstood mining”. Your three-stage description of mining is broadly accepted,  but it doesn’t prove that earlier descriptions were false, only that you believe they were inefficient or unnecessary. Inefficiency is not  impossibility, and refinement not  cover-up. So we’re back at the same distinction: You are arguing that evolving technical descriptions imply incompetence. I am saying that, absent of a disclosed contradiction, that conclusion is not established fact, yet you claim it fact in an authoritative manner, without context of how and why  we are expected to give you credit, or even benefit of doubt.  Why would i buy double glazing of a person off a person who cannot quantify their technical knowledge and authoritative views  of the products. Readers can decide which interpretation they find more persuasive , but it’s important to be clear about where disclosure ends and inference begins.

data.author: Phimx
data.content: Mickdj You post " You say “Gardin has continually changed the story”, yet you haven’t demonstrated a contradiction in the RNSs, only that your interpretation has shifted as new descriptions were released" The story from the introduction of Method C was the Oracle had to run on the hashing ASIc. I don't think that is in dispute, go read several RNS and listen to interviews. My observation is, that was incorrect. Why was that? Because Gardin didn't understand the hashing/mining process. This at odds with his admissions of having a team of around 20 experts working for him. As I have explained creating headers to be hashed by a 1 TH/s miner should be possible but the time to evaluate each new header is unknown. Note by headers I mean modification of the header template provided by the pool by changing the Merkle root (as the extra-NONCE) but before it is sent to the ASIC I speculate that Gardin finally realised how hashing was being performed by the ASIC and realised that an Oracle on an ASIC was not necessary. To be clear hashing of the header can be divided into 3 basic stages 1.  Assemble the header from the information supplied by the pool, there is only one supplied. Performed by.  the control system 2. Send to ASIC and hash with  4.3 billion different NONCEs. If no result 3. Change Merkle root to create new variation of the original header, again performed by control system and repeat. My conclusion from the above: The story has changed it changed because of ignorance rather than development but you can spin it as development if you wish. But without doubt you have to ask the question, where was the expertise when this ASIC/FPGA scheme was being developed when any amateur miner could have probably told Gardin how mining worked. It also complements the fiasco with the CGMiner software.

The Merkle root acts as the extra NONCE field and can provide many more NONCE values than the designated NONCE field

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: This is a classic example of conclusion-first reasoning wrapped in technical verbosity. A few key points for readers: Header vs instance is being deliberately collapsed The post repeatedly asserts that a “header” and an “instance of a header” are the same thing. They are not used interchangeably in QBT’s disclosures. Instances refer to nonce-variant hash attempts. Header assessment refers to evaluating block templates / header states before committing full ASIC hash cycles. Re-labelling them as identical is the author’s interpretation, not a fact established by QBT or the RNS. Throughput arguments miss the architectural claim The argument assumes the Oracle must compete with ASIC throughput on a like-for-like basis. That is not what Method C claims. The claim is probabilistic pre-selection, not brute-force substitution. Saying “ASICs are faster” is irrelevant if the process being described is filtering, not hashing. “He changed the story” is assertion, not evidence What’s actually happened is an evolution from hardware to software description as different implementations are explored. That is explicitly disclosed. No evidence is provided that anything has been “covered up” ,only that the author now disagrees with the interpretation. Speculation is being presented as forensic conclusion Phrases like “we deduce”, “the reality is”, and “Gardin didn’t understand” are opinion, not fact — yet they are framed as definitive findings. In short, this post does not introduce new information. It repackages a negative conclusion using technical language, relies on disputed definitions, and then treats those disputes as proof of failure. Readers can decide whether that advances understanding , or simply reinforces a predetermined narrative.

data.author: Phimx
data.content: Method C software running on the operating system of the miner performs real time assessment of different headers, we are told by the web site.  The first puzzle is what does Gardin mean by different headers. The header template provided by the pool forms the core of the header to be hashed. Most fields are immutable but 2 fields are very important and mutable, the Merkle root and the 32-bit NONCE field. To form different headers these fields are changed to produce trillions of slightly different headers.  The NONCE field has one job, to cycle or increment from 0 to 4.3 billion. For a 1 TH/s miner this takes 8.6 ms, a mere blink of an eye. Every time a single bit changes in the Merkle root the NONCE cycles through 4.3 billion values for that variation of the header. Of course for multi chip ASIC rigs  the time drops equivalently, the latest mining rigs  can achieve 1,000 TH/s so will cycle the NONCE in 8.6 microseconds. What happens to the header after assessment by the Oracle is complete?  We know the answer to that “ this approach avoids processing a large number of headers which have little, or no probability to generate a hash above the pool target” In other words that header is discarded and is not hashed, as we have been led to believe from previous descriptions of Method C.  How is this different from the brute force approach using “instances of Headers” ? Again from the web site description “ Unlike current standard BTC mining approach, based on a search, where the mining rig runs as many Tera hashes per second as possible, during the circa” 10 minutes allowance for each block, with no special criteria on which instances of the header to process first, also described as brute force” We deduce that an instance of a header is simply a specific header, what at one time was called an input to SHA256. Conclusion: In a word salad, Gardin has just described the hardware method C as the software method. He claims the software method is now possible because headers are assessed and not instances but they are the same thing. The reality is Gardin didn’t understand the hashing process, and neither did I. The hardware version never needed an ASIC to operate, it had the time period whilst the 4.3 billion NONCEs were being rolled to construct a new header. For a 1 TH/s hasher that time was 8.3 ms probably sufficient for a fast microprocessor to create a new header and assess if it was worth hashing. Gardin has continually changed the story as he has learned and covered up the flaws in his story. So much for a team of experts !

data.author: fleccy
data.content: Now who's creating their own narrative Mikey? I asked AI the question: "in business terms does product/service delivery suggest revenue is being generated? In business and accounting terms, yes, the delivery of a product or service is the primary indicator that revenue is being generated and can be officially recorded. Under the accrual accounting method—the standard for most mid-to-large businesses and public companies—revenue is recognized when it is earned, which occurs at the moment of delivery, regardless of when the customer actually pays. Revenue Recognition Principles The relationship between delivery and revenue is governed by the Revenue Recognition Principle (standardized internationally as IFRS 15 and in the U.S. as ASC 606). These standards state that revenue is recognized when a company satisfies its performance obligation by transferring control of a good or service to a customer. Product Delivery: Revenue is typically recognized at a single point in time when physical possession or legal title transfers to the buyer. Service Delivery: Revenue is often recognized over time as the service is performed. For example, a monthly subscription service generates revenue incrementally each day the service is available to the user"

data.author: Mikeydj

What it has delivered and disclosed are patent filings, working prototypes, lab validation, and third-party testing programmes under NDA. If your claim is that R&D-stage delivery is meaningless unless revenue already exists, then the disagreement is philosophical, not factual. data.content: I've watched QBT for a good few years now and the music's still playing, but the record's stuck. I'm curious to know why anyone still believes that QBT's business model will lead to anything commercially viable? Am I wrong in saying that the company has released a series of varying narratives over the years, but no evidence of any real substantive progress? You've had Method's A, B, C, SAAS, ASIC development and Quantum, with commercialisation usually touted to arrive in the following year, but then it all goes quiet before a new narrative comes out. I'm not saying QBT aren't trying to achieve their commercial goals, but are those goals viable on their budget? How many registered employee's does the company have? Are the researchers and developers just working on the projects in their spare time, more like hobbyists who might reap future reward? My view is that the miners who spend Billions building datacenters and filling them with rigs, likely have far larger budgets to develop their own proprietary software and systems to enhance their mining operations, and protect the secrecy of their systems to maintain advantage over competitors. Something else to consider is that with each halving mining profits reduce and Datacenters are likely to move operations away from mining and into AI. I've always believed that Bitcoin is built on false narratives and will eventually fail for whatever reason. Maybe power hungry AI will displace Crypto mining as the next big thing, since AI appears to be the next big thing to bubble up; I can see how AI is useful, whereas I view Bitcoin as useless. Will AI finally kill Bitcoin? Maybe. AI is as power hungry as BTC mining, the Datacenters will likely choose one over another dependent on ROI, I believe AI will win over BTC mining.

data.author: Catmangi
data.content: Based on Quantum Blockchain Technologies’ (LSE: QBT) most recent financial reports and historical fundraising patterns, here is an analysis of their likely cash runway and funding needs. 1. Current Cash Position and Burn Rate - Cash Balance: As of June 30, 2025, QBT reported a cash position of €1.7 million. This was a significant increase from €600,000 at the end of 2024, largely due to a fundraising "placing" in January 2025. ​ - Administrative Expenses: The company reported administrative expenses of €1.5 million for the first half of 2025 (H1 2025). ​ - Estimated Burn Rate: Based on these figures, QBT's average monthly burn rate (operational overhead and R&D) is approximately €250,000 per month. 2. Estimated Runway Calculation Assuming the burn rate remains consistent (or slightly increases as they move into commercialization): - Total Funds as of July 2024: €1.7 million. ​ - Estimated Monthly Burn: ~€250,000. ​ - Calculated Runway: Approximately 6.8 months from the end of June 2025. This would place their "zero cash" date around January or February 2026. 3. Likely Timing for the Next Placing Publicly traded R&D companies rarely wait until their cash reaches zero to raise more capital, as they need a buffer for "going concern" status in audits. - Q1 2026 Expectation: QBT has established a pattern of raising funds in the first quarter of the year (e.g., their placing in January 2025). ​ - Trigger Points: Investors should watch for a placing announcement in early 2026, likely coinciding with updates on their ASIC manufacturer partnership or further progress on the SIPEM legal recovery. 4. Factors That Could Change the Timing - Commercial Revenue: If QBT successfully licenses its "Method C" AI Oracle to a major mining pool or ASIC manufacturer in late 2025, they could generate upfront licensing fees that extend their runway without a share placing. ​ - SIPEM Damages: While a Venice court awarded them €6.2 million, the 2025 appeal process means this cash is unlikely to arrive in time to prevent the next funding round. ​ - R&D Acceleration: If they choose to fast-track the hardware production of their binary decision tree chips, the burn rate could spike, necessitating a placing sooner (late Q4 2025). Summary: Unless a significant licensing deal is signed before the end of the year, QBT will likely need to conduct a new share placing by January–March 2026 to ensure sufficient working capital for the remainder of that year.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: The addition of Canaccord as a second market maker generally improves liquidity and price transparency, because it introduces competition into the quoting process. If one market maker were hypothetically suppressing price through wider spreads, slower bid support, or inventory positioning, another market maker can step in to compete for order flow by offering tighter spreads or better pricing. Multiple market makers also distribute risk and reduce reliance on a single liquidity provider, which can make it harder for any one participant to influence short-term price direction. In practice, this usually leads to smoother trading, improved execution for buyers and sellers, and a more balanced order book.

data.content: Quantum Blockchain Technologies (QBT) has transitioned from research to real-time, live testing of its AI-driven Bitcoin mining technologies (Method A, B, and C) as of early 2026, with the commercialization phase imminent. Here is the status of QBT's production timeline: Software Commercialization Phase: QBT is currently transitioning from R&D to commercial application, having entered into three Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs) with ASIC manufacturers to test its Method C AI Oracle on their mining rigs at its Milan laboratory. Live Testing (2026): As of Feb 2026, QBT reported progress on integrating its software with third-party hardware following meetings at the Nashville Energy & Mining Summit. Shift to Software Focus: QBT deprioritized a hardware-based chip in favor of a software-based approach (SaaS), which allows for a faster rollout, with commercialization expected "later this year". Operational Focus: The company is currently engaged in "fine-tuning" its algorithms, with CEO Francesco Gardin indicating that the company is on the verge of turning its technology into commercial products. While no specific "launch date" for mass production was given in the Feb 2026, the company is in the final phases of testing and transitioning toward active commercial deployment in the 2025-2026 cycle

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: Readers deserve full context when strong certainty claims are repeatedly made on this board. In January 2025, riceyboy84 posted: • Called negative posters “parasites”, “cretins” and “boiler room crew” • Claimed the share price was being manipulated by corrupt MMs and media • Said investors selling at lows “deserved to lose their money” • Stated QBT had “massive potential” • Suggested criticism and negative coverage were coordinated attempts to drive price down Today, the same poster is repeatedly posting: • Certainty claims that the company is finished • Predictions of insolvency, investigation and delisting • Statements presenting company failure as current fact rather than opinion • Repeated worst-case scenario outcomes with little or no new evidence Changing your investment view is completely legitimate. Everyone does it. But switching from extreme bullish conviction to extreme failure certainty while presenting both as “fact” raises serious credibility questions. Investors should ask themselves: • Was the original bullish certainty wrong? • Is the current bearish certainty evidence-based or emotionally driven? • Why is the same certainty language being used in opposite directions? • Is the goal discussion — or sentiment influence? This matters because newer investors often assume long-term posters are consistent, reliable or evidence-driven. Posting history here shows conviction has flipped 180° while the communication style has stayed the same — strong certainty, emotive language, and persuasion framing. That is not balanced analysis. That is narrative positioning. Readers should be extremely cautious when any poster: • Presents opinion as fact • Uses absolute outcome language repeatedly • Shifts stance dramatically while maintaining certainty tone • Focuses on emotional reaction rather than verifiable data The safest investment decisions are always based on: • Official RNS disclosures • Verifiable technical or commercial milestones • Independent research • Not forum personalities or conviction strength Always review full posting history — not just current sentiment.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: Reality Check – Pattern Recognition vs “Just Discussion” Nobody is saying posters can’t be negative. Criticism is part of investing forums. But pretending recurring posting waves are just random discussion is increasingly hard to accept when the same usernames appear, using the same themes, at the same trigger points. Let’s be blunt. Every RNS or interview release is followed by a near-identical sequence: • Immediate worst-case certainty posts (failure, insolvency, delisting, fraud suggestions) • Follow-up reinforcement posts comparing QBT to historic AIM failures • Long retrospective posts selectively quoting historic RNS lines to construct failure narratives • Additional posts reframing progress delays as proof of incompetence or deception • Short one-liners reinforcing “consensus negativity” This is not new. It is predictable,repeated and reported. Calling the company a “skeleton non commercial project” is not fact — it is opinion. Stating opinion as inevitability repeatedly is narrative building, not analysis. Claiming AIM losses justify assuming failure here is also flawed logic. Risk exists across AIM. It is not evidence of outcome for any specific company. No issue with scepticism. The issue is when scepticism is presented as certainty and repeated until newer investors assume it is established truth. Readers should ask themselves: • Are new facts being introduced? • Or are historic statements being recycled to reinforce sentiment? • Are timelines being debated fairly or selectively? • Are posters invested or repeatedly focused on discouraging investment? Debate is healthy. Narrative campaigning is something different.

These posts frequently appear early and set a negative sentiment anchor. wyt3fr0g and occasionally Pedrobull Often follow with short reinforcement comments or comparisons to failed AIM companies. These tend to increase perceived consensus rather than introduce new information. Phimx Frequently then builds longer posts quoting RNS history, highlighting contradictions or delays, and directly challenges bullish posters. This often provides technical justification to earlier sentiment posts. Hexam Often reinforces technical or commercial plausibility concerns using conditional logic (for example questioning whether testing has worked or whether partners are engaged). This tends to add credibility to earlier sceptical arguments. UserSteve Regularly expands discussions into historical company performance, long-term revenue absence, and share price decline over many years. This often reframes current debate into a broader historic failure narrative. Plutuq Often reinforces investor frustration or timeline disappointment themes, particularly around delivery expectations versus results. Again, none of the above means any poster is correct or incorrect. It simply shows how forum sentiment can build through layered interaction between the same regular contributors. Readers may find it useful to separate: • Evidence in official disclosures • Interpretation of that evidence • Repetition of narratives • Emotional certainty language . Explore these users posting history (it reveals a lot) Always worth forming your own view based on primary company information rather than thread momentum. Just sharing as an observation for awareness, particularly for newer investors who may not have seen how these discussion cycles tend to repeat.

data.author: Phimx
data.content: It took one and a half years to realise they could not test because the Oracle was not integrated onto the tester's ASIC. It is unbelievable that any ASIC manufacturer would not understand the requirements to carry out a detailed evaluation from day1. Evaluating and testing FPGA and ASIC designs represent a very big percentage of the manufacturing cycle. This is just too absurd  to be true. Who was paying for all the work to be done? There was no contract/deal announced, compare with the recent interview and the claims that legal paperwork has to be completed on top of the NDAs. RNS: 24 June 2024 " QBT is currently collaborating with two ASIC chip manufacturers who are about to begin detailed evaluations of Method " RNS 5 December 2025 " Joint analysis of the hardware version of Method C AI Oracle had previously commenced with one of the three ASIC manufacturers, as announced on 8 April 2025. However, due to the need for the hardware version to be integrated into the ASIC architecture, a process which could take up to 18 months for the new chip to come to market, it has been mutually agreed to give operational priority to the new software version, as a commercial roll-out is expected to be achieved much faster with this approach. Therefore, in light of the above, QBT's involvement in a design collaboration for a new ASIC with this or any other ASIC manufacturer will now represent the second phase of any commercial relationship, following a successful roll-out of the software version of Method C."

data.author: mrhanji
data.content: AI Overview Based on recent interviews with Proactive Investors, Quantum Blockchain Technologies PLC (AIM:QBT) is in a high-intensity phase of commercializing its AI-driven Bitcoin mining technology, with a particular focus on its "Method C" AI Oracle. Here are the key takeaways from recent QBT interviews with CEO Francesco Gardin: 1. Key Technology Developments Method C AI Oracle: This is the main focus, designed to improve the efficiency of existing ASIC mining hardware. It has been refined to operate in real-time using FPGA hardware, with the aim of achieving roughly a 30% increase in "quality hashes" (efficiency). Software-Only Deployment: To accelerate time-to-market, QBT shifted from a hardware-intensive approach to a software-only version of Method C, cutting deployment time from 18 months to just a few weeks. Methods A & B: These methods are also being developed, with ongoing negotiations to integrate them into aftermarket control boards for mining rigs. 2. Commercialization & Strategic Partnerships ASIC Partnerships: QBT has signed multiple Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs) with major, but unnamed, ASIC manufacturers to test the Method C AI Oracle on their machines. Testing Phase: The company is currently testing its technology in a Milan laboratory, focusing on legacy S9 miners as a proof of concept. Target Market: The technology is aimed at helping smaller or mid-sized miners, as well as those using older hardware, to close the efficiency gap with market leaders. Revenue Model: QBT is exploring several revenue avenues, including licensing fees, share of hash rates (profit sharing), and direct mining. 3. Recent Strategic Updates (Late 2025/Early 2026) Positive Feedback: The technology was well-received at a recent US Bitcoin conference, validating the company's direction. IP Strategy: QBT is focusing on patenting its core AI Oracle technology, though some developments are kept as trade secrets. The company describes this period as a "very, very intense and busy" time as they move towards full commercialization of their proprietary AI, which aims to boost hashing power without requiring significant extra energy.

data.author: UserSteve
data.content: In the interview the host says "...there's been confusion around partial access to source code..." I find this very interesting. This appears to be about this statement in the 4 Feb 2026 RNS: "It should be noted that partial access to source code has already been granted to the Company. " The RNS came out at 7am. And just a few hours later the interview came out addressing tge confusion this statement caused. So, within a few hours after the 7am publication,  presumably QBT received several calls to clarify this statement, and were able to include addressing the issue in the interview. All within a few hours. Quite impressive, really. If only QBT responded to calls for clarification in this manner on a regular basis!!

data.author: UserSteve
data.content: From Oct 2025 to today. bitcoin has dropped 50% from $125k to $64k. In the same period QBT's share price has dropped 17% from 0.63p to 0.525p When bitcoin did a 6-bagger, QBT fell. When bitcoin halved in value, QBT fell. Thus there is no relationship between BTC and QBT prices. To me, this strongly suggests that the market knows that QBT is not related to BTC. Rather, the market knows that QBT is oprtating in another area. QBT's spikes have been on the back of hopeful RNSs, all of which failed to result in deals and revenue. So it seems to me that QBT's main 'product' is hope itself, which it sellsto the market by way of fundraises. And this hope is often hyped by Gardin during interviews. Just my take on things. Will happily be proved wrong by the announcement of a material commercial deal, or by the publishing of validation of QBT's Methods by an trusted independent company (such as one of the Big 4)  or reputable newspaper (such as The Financial Times or Computer Weekly).

data.author: UserSteve
data.content: [Part 2 of 2] ... we can start to develop our method on this open source platform, and that the expectation is that now that these three ASIC manufacturer [sic] will be selling their chips, unlike what the Chinese have been, manufacturer have been doing so far that they don't sell their chip, you have to de-solder their chip from a machine to use them. So this is creating a new, entirely new situation in the sector. Finally you have chips available in quantities, and you have already have the entire design of a system, of, of, a, a, an ecosystem for mining, and this is for us is a game-changer because we expect, or the industry expect, that there will be many manufacturers who will assemble systems, starting from this open source designs, and therefore there will be more companies offering their systems, which will bring a very healthy change in this market dominated by 99% by the three manufacturers in China. Host: Francesco, there's been confusion around partial access to source code. Can you explain in simple terms what access QBT has today, and what it doesn't yet have? Gardin: Yeah, that's has to do with the three, ahh, umm, with three partners, the ASIC manufacturers, because there is substantial amount of source code and they start to release it to us, err, umm, partially, er, because, er, erm, we wouldn't have anyway the, the ability to deal with three, err, different operating system [sic], ahh, three different drivers, and so that's something that is going on incrementally, err, but, ahh, it's, it's part of, of an agreed, ahh, erm, path, er, that, er, we have, er, defined with this, er, three potential partners. Host: Mmm. I mean, ahh, investors are keen to understand progress with those partners. How would you describe the current stage of those relationships and why the phase is taking time? Gardin: Ahhh, well, I mean *laughs* the, say that, ahh, the main focus with the three manufacturers, but not the only but main work focus is Method C. Method C you need to train the neural network [sic] and train it on the specific ASICs that will be in the machine. So the training is very ASIC oriented, specific ASIC oriented, and that's not something you do overnight, and to get these machines there is legal paperwork because one thing is to sign an NDA, the other thing is to sign all the guarantees for the software, the proprietary software that they share, the design of this ASIC because we need to understand how they work internally, the specs of these ASICs which are not necessarily in the public domain, so, I mean, it's not as simple as I sign an NDA, I come and pick up a machine tomorrow. *laughs and shakes head* Unfortunately it doesn't work like that. Host: Francesco, hope you'll continue to keep us updated with your progress, thank you very much for your time today. Gardin: Thank you Host: Francesco Gardin, the CEO of Quantum Blockchain Technologies.

data.author: UserSteve
data.content: Francesco Gardin interview 4 Feb 2026 This thread contains a transcript of the Proactive Investors interview with Francesco Gardin on 4 Feb 2026 (Link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=73Vn7tzv1iI) The full interview starts at time 0:20. The first few words spoken from time 00:00 to 00:18 are a repeat of what was stated in the full interview at time 05:06 to 05:24. My transcript covers the full complete interview from 0:20 onwards; it does not contain the repeated words. This transcript was generated solely by me by hand (and ears) without using any tools or sources other than a word processor and listening to the YouTube video. I have not used any transcript generated by YouTube or any other software, tool, or source. ------------------- [Part 1 of 2] Host: Hello, you're watching Proactive. I'm joined by Francesco Gardin, the CEO of Quantum Blockchain Technologies. Francesco, very good to speak with you. Your update todays follows a positive industry conference rather than a single breakthrough. What was the key takeaway for QBT from attending the Nashville event? Gardin: Ok, good morning, Stephen. Ahh, the Bitcoin Park in Nashville is one of the center [sic] ah, in the US of the bitcoin culture. And so, ah, attending this events is always very important because it's the best way to network with the real professionals in the sector. Err, so it's been, ahh, one-and-a-half days but extremely intensive with the many, many, many, many side meetings that we had with the main players, especially with three, ahh, manufacturers of ASIC [sic] for bitcoin mining that we, ah, have signed the NDA with, and we are progressing, ahh, work with them, which is extremely good, and it's also good to show your face there and to show your physical presence together with our US consultants. Ahh, the, errm, so this is part of the normal commercial relationship, err, business relationship that you have to entertain and also monitor any development in the industry. Apart from this, it was very important for us also because one of the major problem that we had to face in the past is that 99% of the market is dominated by the Chinese manufacturers, and their policy is that no specs on the ASICs, err, and no availability of access to the software which runs on their mining rigs. Therefore that fact that now, finally, other after this gigantic effort, ahh, there is this whole stack available which is open source from the design of the hashing boards, design of control boards, the software which controls it, the even a pool, now is all open source which means that we can, ah, ah, as well as working with the three partners, the ASIC manufacturers, ... [continued in part 2]

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: For balance, the recent RNS can also be viewed constructively: • QBT confirmed continued engagement with ASIC manufacturers who have signed NDAs, suggesting partnerships remain in place and active. • The RNS states partial access to source code has already been granted, which may indicate progress into deeper technical collaboration rather than early-stage discussions. • Discussions around hardware and software delivery timelines suggest projects are moving toward integration and testing phases. • The RNS highlights QBT’s ability to work alongside emerging open-source mining hardware platforms, which could expand potential commercial routes and reduce supplier dependency. • Continued attendance at industry conferences supports relationship building, technical monitoring, and commercial visibility within the mining sector. The RNS does not announce immediate revenue or contract milestones but may indicate that development and partnership processes remain ongoing rather than stalled. Again, Investors should consider both positive signals and associated risks when interpreting company updates, and be mindful the consistent naysaying   rhetoric from the majority of the posters.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: For balance, If you remove the share bashers that popped out of the woodwork today  (as they always do on RNS days)  the interview can also be viewed positively in several ways: • QBT confirmed ongoing engagement with three ASIC manufacturers under NDAs, suggesting partnerships remain active. • Partial source code access indicates collaboration has progressed beyond early discussions into technical integration stages. • ASIC-specific training and legal/licensing steps help explain development timelines and reflect normal hardware/AI co-development complexity. • The emergence of open-source mining hardware could reduce reliance on dominant Chinese suppliers and create wider commercial opportunities. • Parallel development (partners + open stack) potentially reduces single-partner risk and increases long-term optionality. The interview does indicate continued technical and partnership progress rather than project inactivity. As always, investors should weigh both opportunities and risks and rely on primary disclosures when forming conclusions. Especially when the hoards are claiming white is black.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: How Narratives Sometimes Form Worth remembering that forum sentiment doesn’t always build randomly. There’s a common pattern that appears across many AIM and small-cap boards and in particular this. RNS brings out droves. It usually starts with a strong negative or positive claim. Then follow-up posts repeat or reinforce it. Over time, repetition can make opinions feel like established facts, even when no new evidence has been added. You have seen this before right ? Another common tactic is presenting complex technical points in a way that suggests confusion or contradiction. Readers can mistake complexity for proof something is wrong. Examples of Common Posting Styles Seen Across Discussions: • Pedrobull – Often posts short, slogan-style negativity or repetition phrases that reinforce sentiment rather than introduce new information. • Phimx – Frequently posts longer technical or RNS-based interpretations, often highlighting perceived contradictions or uncertainty in company communications. • riceyboy84 – Commonly posts timeline predictions and worst-case scenario outcomes such as delisting or failure, usually framed as inevitability. • KoolKat15 – Often focuses on investor protection arguments, confidence issues, and the absence of revenue or deals, typically presented in detailed opinion posts. • allforprofit – Tends to use strong criticism of leadership capability or company direction, often framed as performance concern commentary. • 0134 – Regularly raises concerns around funding, placings, or financial sustainability speculation. • Plutuq – Often posts probability or price prediction style commentary suggesting likely short-term trading outcomes. • Awl007 – Typically posts shorter reinforcement or agreement style comments that echo broader sentiment already expressed. • mrhanji – Usually posts bullish outlook commentary, often focusing on potential partnerships, future valuation upside, or encouraging holders to ignore negative sentiment. These observations relate to posting style patterns only and form part of normal forum debate dynamics seen across many shares and boards. But WHY so many self proclaimed uninvested users spreading negativity ? None of this means criticism or support is invalid. Healthy debate is important. It simply means investors should separate: • Evidence • Interpretation • Repetition • Emotion Always worth checking source material yourself rather than relying purely on forum consensus.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: Common pattern seen on this thread: 🔹 Technical scepticism usually starts with posters like Phimx and UserSteve They quote RNS wording, highlight contradictions, and build logical arguments suggesting delays or lack of clarity. 🔹 Strategic doubt often follows from posters like Hexam They expand the discussion into partner engagement, company direction, or credibility of progress. 🔹 Emotional escalation then appears via posters like riceyboy84 and avocet123 This is where language shifts towards “jam tomorrow”, funding fears, or leadership criticism. 🔹 Confidence erosion framing is often reinforced by KoolKat15 Posts focus on lack of revenue, investor risk, and long-term trust concerns. 🔹 Echo reinforcement typically comes from shorter posts by Badboxer, MDL26, Drutor, and Plutuq These reinforce sentiment through humour, certainty statements, or price predictions. 🔹 Bullish counter arguments usually come from mrhanji Posts highlight potential deals, progress indicators, and future rerate scenarios. 🔹 Neutral sentiment or market reaction comments often appear from Awl007 and oldsharedog None of this means anyone is right or wrong. It simply shows how forum sentiment can build through layered interaction rather than single opinions. Again have you seen these names interacting before? Always worth separating: • Evidence • Interpretation • Repetition • Emotion

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: There’s a big gap between the hype generated on bulletin boards and what’s actually happening with QBT. The hype is built on: extrapolating worst-case interpretations, recycling old quotes out of context, asserting certainty where there is none, and treating opinion or inference as if it were established fact. What’s actually happening is simpler: QBT has been running an R&D programme with multiple approaches, descriptions have evolved as implementations are tested, progress has been slower than hoped (as is common in R&D), and outcomes ultimately depend on independent verification, not forum rhetoric. None of that proves success, but neither does repetition of negative narratives prove failure. The only things that will settle this are evidence, testing results, and disclosures. Until then, most of what’s posted here is noise layered on top of opinion. Readers should separate certainty-sounding posts from verifiable facts, and decide accordingly.

data.author: Mikeydj

The disclosures say what they say, interviews say what they say, and the outcome is known. Readers can draw their own conclusions from the primary sources. There’s nothing further of substance to add here.

data.author: UserSteve
data.content: Mikeydj said "The RNS said 'NDA signed' and “'ocus on development',  it did not commit to manufacture, spend, or production. " I agree with you, Mikeydj. The RNS most definitely did not say that they *will* produce an ASIC. But in the 3 Dec 2021 public interview, their CEO Gardin *did* say that QBT's target was to produce an ASIC that was, at a minumum, twice as fast as the keading ASIC at the time, within one year. His guidance is not caveated; these are stated as definites. Gardin states "The chip that *we will produce*...". This is definite guidance with no caveats, if, buts, mights, or maybes. Gardin also states the chip "...will be more faster than just twice as much. Twice as much faster is the minimum target for our chip...". Again, this is definite performance guidance with no caveats. Gardin also states "I emphasise that [these results] are a 1 year away target.". Here the CEO is giving guidance that their target is to produce the ASIC in a year. No caveats at all. There are two ways to look at this. The first is to accept that QBT completely failed to achieve their guidance target stated publically by their CEO. The second is to accept that anything their CEOs say in public interviews is unreliable, may not reflect reality, and should not be used to influence your investment decisions.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: To be clear, no one suggested a 5nm ASIC costs “£32”. The point is that 5nm costs vary enormously depending on scope, IP reuse, verification depth, and whether work is development, prototyping, or mass production. Presenting a single headline figure as universally applicable , even if described as “design only” , still ignores those variables. Sarcasm doesn’t change that technical reality.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: The RNS said “NDA signed” and “focus on development”, it did not commit to manufacture, spend, or production. Quoting a single $449m 5nm cost figure applies to full-scale SoC programmes, not automatically to every ASIC concept or development path. Interviews are not guidance and don’t override what is (and isn’t) stated in RNS disclosures. Collapsing those distinctions into “we know it was impossible” isn’t analysis, it’s framing. Readers can judge intent by comparing what was actually committed to in writing versus how it’s being retrospectively portrayed.

data.author: UserSteve
data.content: While the RNS very clearly does not state that QBT intends to actually make the 5nm ASIC, investors could be forgiven for believing that this was their intention. Investors would have got this impresdion from the public statements of CEO Gardin during the 3 Dec 2021 Proactive Investor interview (link at bottom). Here are some of Gardin's statements regarding the ASIC: At 03:05 Gardin says "It was quite complex to be able to attract the attention of this large [5nm ASIC] manufacturer and actually being able to engage them and to book some production time at the beginning of Q1 2023" At 04:14 Gardin says "The chip that we will produce will be far more faster than just twice as much. Twice as much faster is the minimum target for our chip, but we are confident that it will be much, much faster when we introduce the results of the second patent" and "I emphasise that [these results] are a 1 year away target." Then at 05:14 Gardin says "We are getting extraordinary results from our AI team which means if we can incorporate those results into our chip, our chip could be 100 times, 1000 times faster." But as Mikeydj rightly posted, interviews are not guidance and can be disregarded. I would go further and will state the obvious: that after this debacle, all of Gardin's claims during interviews can be safely ignored as hopelessly fantastical delusions of grandeur which have never have and never will be borne out in the real world. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uyx67cydEMI

data.author: UserSteve
data.content: Ah yes, but you need to identify the multiple caveats used in the RNS, "focus" and "develoment": "...it has made the key decision to *focus on* the *development of* the more efficient 5nm ... ASIC..." They only said they were going to *focus on it*, they never said they were going to actually make one. And they only said they were going to focus on the *development* of one, they never said they were going to actually make one. So it was there in black and white that they only intended to have a look into it, they never said they intended to make one. All QBT's RNSs must be very carefully read to identify the caveats used. When you do, you will find that they claim or intend to do very little indeed.

data.author: Phimx
data.content: 30 November 2021: Gardin states " NDA signed to provide QBT with 5nm Technology for Proprietary Bitcoin mining ASIC The board of Quantum Blockchain Technologies (AIM: QBT) is pleased to announce that it has made the key decision to focus on the development of the more efficient 5nm Application-Specific Integrated Circuit (“ASIC”), rather than a 7nm ASIC (as announced on 5 November 2021), to use as its proprietary Bitcoin mining tool." In 2023 ARM INC estimated the cost of producing a 5 nm ASIC at $449 Million. Make your own decision as to how feasible and probable that was ! With hindsight, in 2026 we know it was and is - highly improbable. More Gardin claims that came to nothing

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: here are specific phrases, labels, and rhetorical constructions used by phimx on many occasions that read to a reasonable reader as implying fraud, deception, or scam-like behaviour. even when he later retreats behind “opinion” or “technical critique”. 1. explicit deception / dishonesty framing these are not neutral technical criticisms , they imply intentional misleading: “gardin has continually changed the story” “covered up the flaws in his story” “layers of bull**** on top of more bull****” “making up the numbers to fit the claims” “chosen to sound plausible to non-engineers” “hand-waving” (repeated in context of official disclosures) these phrases frame management behaviour as knowingly deceptive rather than mistaken or speculative. 2. competence / dishonesty escalation this is a classic technique: start with “ignorance”, end at fraud: “gardin didn’t understand the hashing process” “neither did i” (false humility used to appear balanced) “where was the expertise?” “no team of experts could have existed” “fantasy” / “abandoned fantasy” “mistaken asic route” “failed asic route”

data.author: Phimx
data.content: Mickydj: You post " On what evidential or professional basis are you asserting that a team of experts could not have existed ? Micky, firstly Google "Source: Arm Inc 2023 IPO Prospectus (IBS, July 2022)" this document by ARM, and they know a bit about ASIC design, shows approximate costs of ASIC manufacture. For a 5 nm ASIC they estimate $449 Million. Yes that's correct $449 Million.  Now it defies believe that a sane man contemplating production of a 5 nm ASIC would not jump on his laptop and do a bit of Googling to establish what he's dealing with ! Or, if he is employing ASIC/FPGA experts, casually ask them at tea break " what would it take to make a 5nm ASIC chaps" I think Gardin, in a RNS. stated something like he had reserved manufacturing time with an ASIC firm. Therefore any sane and sensible person would, I think, be astonished that Gardin did not know the cost. Apparently from subsequent RNS he persisted with the idea, even to this day. But the cost realisation eventually filtered through to him and he abandoned that particular fantasy. Maybe I am wrong perhaps his team did say, "hey man that's an awesome cost" but he carried on making announcements of building the fastest industry leading ASIC without any solid foundation for doing so. No public attempts were made to raise money it seems. So, I believe there were no 20 or so 'experts' because he continued to make RNS statements apparently oblivious to the cost and complexity of the project. He was also not being advised that hashing and Method C hardware did not actually require an Oracle on an ASIC. Additionally he was oblivious to the fact that throwing away 30% of your header inputs actually provides a 43% hashing rate increase, as shown by statements in several RNS. The alternative is, there is a team of world class experts but Gardin chose to ignore their advice and continued to make claims he had very little chance of achieving. My qualification, I can read.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: So, to be clear, are you saying that YES you did  very much do in fact use the term “covered up” in this thread below ?, i did not see a reply. What you are describing is your reconstruction of how Method C must have evolved, based on your current understanding of mining architecture. That is not the same thing as demonstrating a contradiction in disclosed statements. Two points matter here: Change of implementation detail is not a contradiction of claim The core claim has remained that an AI-driven oracle can influence which work is prioritised or discarded before full hashing. Whether that logic sits on an ASIC, FPGA, control board, or software layer  is an implementation choice, not a reversal of principle. R&D projects routinely move functionality across layers as constraints are better understood. You are explicitly speculating about motives and competence Phrases like “I speculate that Gardin finally realised…” and “ignorance rather than development” are interpretations, not facts. You may believe them to be likely, but they are not supported by any evidence stating “this approach was abandoned because we misunderstood mining”. Your three-stage description of mining is broadly accepted,  but it doesn’t prove that earlier descriptions were false, only that you believe they were inefficient or unnecessary. Inefficiency is not  impossibility, and refinement not  cover-up. So we’re back at the same distinction: You are arguing that evolving technical descriptions imply incompetence. I am saying that, absent of a disclosed contradiction, that conclusion is not established fact, yet you claim it fact in an authoritative manner, without context of how and why  we are expected to give you credit, or even benefit of doubt.  Why would i buy double glazing of a person off a person who cannot quantify their technical knowledge and authoritative views  of the products. Readers can decide which interpretation they find more persuasive , but it’s important to be clear about where disclosure ends and inference begins.

data.author: Phimx
data.content: Mickdj You post " You say “Gardin has continually changed the story”, yet you haven’t demonstrated a contradiction in the RNSs, only that your interpretation has shifted as new descriptions were released" The story from the introduction of Method C was the Oracle had to run on the hashing ASIc. I don't think that is in dispute, go read several RNS and listen to interviews. My observation is, that was incorrect. Why was that? Because Gardin didn't understand the hashing/mining process. This at odds with his admissions of having a team of around 20 experts working for him. As I have explained creating headers to be hashed by a 1 TH/s miner should be possible but the time to evaluate each new header is unknown. Note by headers I mean modification of the header template provided by the pool by changing the Merkle root (as the extra-NONCE) but before it is sent to the ASIC I speculate that Gardin finally realised how hashing was being performed by the ASIC and realised that an Oracle on an ASIC was not necessary. To be clear hashing of the header can be divided into 3 basic stages 1.  Assemble the header from the information supplied by the pool, there is only one supplied. Performed by.  the control system 2. Send to ASIC and hash with  4.3 billion different NONCEs. If no result 3. Change Merkle root to create new variation of the original header, again performed by control system and repeat. My conclusion from the above: The story has changed it changed because of ignorance rather than development but you can spin it as development if you wish. But without doubt you have to ask the question, where was the expertise when this ASIC/FPGA scheme was being developed when any amateur miner could have probably told Gardin how mining worked. It also complements the fiasco with the CGMiner software.

data.author: Mikeydj
data.content: This is a classic example of conclusion-first reasoning wrapped in technical verbosity. A few key points for readers: Header vs instance is being deliberately collapsed The post repeatedly asserts that a “header” and an “instance of a header” are the same thing. They are not used interchangeably in QBT’s disclosures. Instances refer to nonce-variant hash attempts. Header assessment refers to evaluating block templates / header states before committing full ASIC hash cycles. Re-labelling them as identical is the author’s interpretation, not a fact established by QBT or the RNS. Throughput arguments miss the architectural claim The argument assumes the Oracle must compete with ASIC throughput on a like-for-like basis. That is not what Method C claims. The claim is probabilistic pre-selection, not brute-force substitution. Saying “ASICs are faster” is irrelevant if the process being described is filtering, not hashing. “He changed the story” is assertion, not evidence What’s actually happened is an evolution from hardware to software description as different implementations are explored. That is explicitly disclosed. No evidence is provided that anything has been “covered up” ,only that the author now disagrees with the interpretation. Speculation is being presented as forensic conclusion Phrases like “we deduce”, “the reality is”, and “Gardin didn’t understand” are opinion, not fact — yet they are framed as definitive findings. In short, this post does not introduce new information. It repackages a negative conclusion using technical language, relies on disputed definitions, and then treats those disputes as proof of failure. Readers can decide whether that advances understanding , or simply reinforces a predetermined narrative.

data.author: Phimx
data.content: Method C software running on the operating system of the miner performs real time assessment of different headers, we are told by the web site.  The first puzzle is what does Gardin mean by different headers. The header template provided by the pool forms the core of the header to be hashed. Most fields are immutable but 2 fields are very important and mutable, the Merkle root and the 32-bit NONCE field. To form different headers these fields are changed to produce trillions of slightly different headers.  The NONCE field has one job, to cycle or increment from 0 to 4.3 billion. For a 1 TH/s miner this takes 8.6 ms, a mere blink of an eye. Every time a single bit changes in the Merkle root the NONCE cycles through 4.3 billion values for that variation of the header. Of course for multi chip ASIC rigs  the time drops equivalently, the latest mining rigs  can achieve 1,000 TH/s so will cycle the NONCE in 8.6 microseconds. What happens to the header after assessment by the Oracle is complete?  We know the answer to that “ this approach avoids processing a large number of headers which have little, or no probability to generate a hash above the pool target” In other words that header is discarded and is not hashed, as we have been led to believe from previous descriptions of Method C.  How is this different from the brute force approach using “instances of Headers” ? Again from the web site description “ Unlike current standard BTC mining approach, based on a search, where the mining rig runs as many Tera hashes per second as possible, during the circa” 10 minutes allowance for each block, with no special criteria on which instances of the header to process first, also described as brute force” We deduce that an instance of a header is simply a specific header, what at one time was called an input to SHA256. Conclusion: In a word salad, Gardin has just described the hardware method C as the software method. He claims the software method is now possible because headers are assessed and not instances but they are the same thing. The reality is Gardin didn’t understand the hashing process, and neither did I. The hardware version never needed an ASIC to operate, it had the time period whilst the 4.3 billion NONCEs were being rolled to construct a new header. For a 1 TH/s hasher that time was 8.3 ms probably sufficient for a fast microprocessor to create a new header and assess if it was worth hashing. Gardin has continually changed the story as he has learned and covered up the flaws in his story. So much for a team of experts !
